items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge due to prolonged rainfall over the last few days.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning, 21/11/2022. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.   
  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 21/11/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Upper River Wey, especially in the Passfield Mill and Godalming areas, as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue this evening (20/11/2022) and overnight into tomorrow (21/11/2022). It is forecast to be a mostly dry evening and night.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Addlestone Bourne as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue this evening (20/11/2022) and overnight into tomorrow (21/11/2022). It is forecast to be a mostly dry evening and night.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The Aldingbourne Rife remains high but has now peaked and will slowly fall through Sunday (20/11/2022). Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the car park at Tesco and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. In Barnham, river levels are already significantly lower than their peak and falling. Any minor flood impacts in Barnham should reduce. Further rain is forecast in the area on Sunday (5-10mm), Monday (15-30mm) and Tuesday (5-20mm) which could cause more flood risk next week. Some roads, including Shripney Lane may be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 21/11/2022.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.92 m and is stable.

The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.13m and is rising by approximately 11mm 

Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.

Pumping will begin at Episcopi pumping station when levels in the river allow.

Dry weather is forecast for today Thursday, 17/11/2022, with the risk of isolated showers.

The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to remain stable

We are closely monitoring the situation.   
  
This message will be updated at 12:00 on Friday, 18/11/2022.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message: River levels continue to rise on the Lower Dorset Stour due to recent rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Wimborne and Christchurch. The forecast for the next 24 hours is for more settled conditions. River levels are rising at the Throop and Wimborne A31 gauge. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River Ouse levels are continuing to fall following prolonged rainfall on 17/11/2022. Flooding remains possible on riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and Naburn, particularly around Naburn Lock. River levels have also peaked at Naburn and will continue to fall slowly. Tidal levels are not currently of concern. Further rainfall is expected later today, and river levels may fluctuate further, remaining high on Sunday night and Monday. The Foss Barrier is no longer in operation. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We anticipate being able to remove this alert. Nevertheless, this message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 21/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We anticipate being able to remove this alert. Nevertheless, this message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 21/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Derwent due to prolonged rainfall over the last few days. Flooding remains possible in locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Old Malton, and Priorpot Beck in Norton this evening, Sunday 20/11/2022, and into tomorrow. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 21/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Derwent due to prolonged rainfall over the last few days. Flooding remains possible in locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around local roads and low-lying land around Buttercrambe, Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington through the weekend. River levels will remain high on Monday but will fall slowly. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 21/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high and still rising slowly on the River Cherwell as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is possible later this evening and overnight 20/11/2022, especially in the Thrupp area.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 2 days. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly this evening, overnight and tomorrow 21/11/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood alert has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

Water levels in the Eastern Yar continue to broadly fall. Whilst the river level at Alverstone is rising slightly in response to the small amount of overnight rainfall, the Eastern Yar at Sandown continues to fall and is now below the level at which Fort Holiday Park is affected. Operation of Bembridge sluices, over the period of Neap tides, has reduced water levels within Brading Marshes and effectively managed the risk of property flooding in Brading. The current weather forecast indicates showers may affect the Eastern Yar catchment this afternoon but only small totals of rain are forecast. Tomorrow morning (21/11/22), a frontal band of rain will potentially bring up to 25mm of rain. This will be followed by showers Monday evening into Tuesday morning (22/11/22), possibly adding an additional 10mm of rain. If realised, this would likely see a Flood Alert issued for the Eastern Yar and potentially Flood Warnings covering the upper and lower Eastern Yar catchment. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. Avoid walking or driving through flood water.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen following recent heavy rainfall. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 
Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow, Monday 21 November, but we do not expect any further flooding at this time. We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 
Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and taking action where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The forecast for today is for mostly dry weather.
We continue to monitor the situation, and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The weather forecast for today is for dry spells with scattered showers. Further rainfall, some of which could be heavy, is forecast for Monday. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.
